A powerful yet compact portable charger

This is a powerful and compact portable charger that lets you charge several electronic devices simultaneously. That makes it a great pick for cell phones, tablets, game consoles, and more. It provides up to 160W of power through each of its USB-C ports, so it can safely and rapidly fast-charge a USB-C laptop while charging two additional devices (phone and/or tablet) at the same time.

The USB-C ports are ideal for providing high-power charging to newer laptops, tablets and smartphones, while the USB-A ports are ideal for charging older phones, Bluetooth speakers and/or other smaller electronic devices. Additionally, the Anker Prime Charger has Power Delivery (PD) capability, enabling it to supply power to your electronic devices at the fastest possible rate, allowing you to charge your devices quicker and more efficiently.

Although the Anker Prime Charger has the potential to deliver a significant amount of power, it‚Äôs still super small. You can put it on a desktop surface, nightstand, or kitchen counter without taking up too much valuable real estate. It‚Äôs also super lightweight and easily storable in a backpack or travel case, making it ideal for use during business trips, vacations, or work-from-home/coworking days, when users would prefer a single charger to replace a tangled mess of individual chargers and cables.

Built-in safety features enable you to feel confident when connecting expensive electronic devices. The Anker Prime Charger constantly monitors temperature and power consumption to ensure that it protects against heat damage (overheating), excessive voltage, and/or electrical shock due to short circuit conditions. Although these protective mechanisms operate transparently, they offer considerable peace-of-mind benefits when you need to charge multiple high-value devices at the same time.

This Anker Prime Charger is absolutely perfect for its size, capacity, and performance. It eliminates clutter, enables fast-charging capabilities for newer devices, and is compatible with both home and travel-based environments. Bottom line? item.title: I‚Äôm Begging For A Sequel After Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles Ships 1 Million Copies
item.content:encoded:
How many more copies does Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles need to sell before Square Enix greenlights a new grid-based strategy RPG? Almost three years later, physical versions of Hi-Fi Rush are finally up for pre-order. And how long will it take for Netflix to turn Arc Raiders into its next streaming hit?

It‚Äôs the latest edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news and culture. Depending on what you‚Äôre into, January will probably feel like a slow month for big new game releases, at least compared to last year. But I‚Äôm getting lowkey hyped for Code Vein 2, the follow-up to the messy 2019 action-RPG anime soulslike. This one has a motorcycle.

Even Final Fantasy Tactics‚Äò original director can‚Äôt believe how well the remaster is selling

I underestimated the sales figures by too much.üòÇüòÇüòÇ

‚Äî ÊùæÈáéÊ≥∞Â∑±üêà‚Äç‚¨õ (@YasumiMatsuno) January 6, 2026

Square Enix revealed that Final Fantasy Tactics: The Ivalice Chronicles has sold over 1 million copies. That might be ‚Äúbelow expectations‚Äù for the infamously disappointed Japanese publisher, but it was enough to take Yasumi Matsuno by surprise. It also prompted a fresh message to fans from the remaster‚Äôs director.

‚ÄúThe entire development team is not only grateful to you, but, in order to spread the joy, create a better experience, and encourage more people to play, we are looking at updating the game in the future!‚Äù Kazutoyo Maehiro wrote, according to a translation from Gamesradar. What does updating the game in the future entail, exactly? Could the missing War of the Lions content be officially restored? Could we get fresh end-game modes?

‚ÄúOur first and foremost goal here really was to recreate the original game,‚Äù Maehiro told Wired last year. ‚ÄúIf [The Ivalice Chronicles] were to become a success,‚Äù he continued, ‚ÄúI do feel that that would then lead to discussions around potentially bringing out sequels, for example, or newer tactical RPGs.‚Äù

Let the Final Fantasy Tactics 2 summoning circle commence.

You can finally pre-order a physical copy of Hi-Fi Rush

The 2023 GOTY contender from Tango Gameworks, a studio that Microsoft closed in 2024 but which was later re-opened under Krafton, is finally getting a physical version that you can start pre-ordering from Limited Run Games on January 23. That includes a PS5 version. This is one game everyone should have in their collection, even if it could still be a year before it actually starts shipping.

We could end up getting an Arc Raiders TV show

Embark studio head Patrick S√∂derlund told GamesBeat that Hollywood is interested and so is he. ‚ÄúWe [wouldn‚Äôt] mind doing that. It would be fun, but it needs to be done in the right way. I hope that we will do that. I think the IP fits quite well with something like that.‚Äù Nothing is set in stone yet, however, and Embark doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúhave anyone working on a TV or film adaptation yet.‚Äù Maybe we‚Äôll see it on Netflix in time for Arc Raiders 2.

Game of Thrones star Sophie Turner was fine with her ending

She acknowledges that the rest of the cast was disappointed with their characters‚Äô fates. ‚ÄúBut I feel that I was very happy with the way Sansa ended her story in Game of Thrones, and no one else was really happy with their ending,‚Äù Turner told The Direct. ‚ÄúI feel like I got a good one, and so I don‚Äôt know if I could revisit it.‚Äù Would she come back to do more Game of Thrones? ‚ÄúShow me the money,‚Äù she joked. She might be too busy with Tomb Raider anyway.

Final Fantasy 9‚Äòs character artist says goodbye

Toshiyuki Itahana left Square Enix at the end of last year. ‚ÄúLast year marked a major milestone with the 25th anniversary of FINAL FANTASY IX, a truly significant event, and I was deeply grateful to see so many people celebrating FFIX,‚Äù he wrote in a message to fans. He‚Äôll continue to produce art as a freelance illustrator.

I love my paperbacks, but over time, I have realized how much more convenient digital copies are for reading on the go. You also get more variety, instead of feeling stuck with that one book you grabbed in a hurry and aren‚Äôt really in the mood for anymore ‚Äì coming from someone who often picks a classic when all that the brain needs is some Murakami.

If you‚Äôre not a fan of reading on your phone or tablet, a Kindle can be an excellent investment. There are multiple versions available, but right now, Amazon is offering a chance to pick the latest Kindle Colorsoft at a nice 20% discount, for just $200. You‚Äôre saving a sweet $50 on a reading solution that makes it easy to have all your favorite titles accessible at all times, wherever you go. Keep All Your Favorite Titles Close

For $200, you‚Äôre getting a modest 7-inch, high-contrast Colorsoft display that‚Äôs easy on the eyes. Unlike the Kindle Paperwhite display, which is optimized for black and white reading, this version brings all the colors to life. It‚Äôs great for stories that include illustrations and maps ‚Äì think The Hobbit, The Lord of the Rings, and The Wheel of Time ‚Äì plus comics where color really enhances the overall experience. You can even highlight your favorite scenes in yellow, orange, blue, or pink, and come back to revisit the moments later.

The brightness is adjustable. You can tweak the display from white to amber, depending on your environment. Switch to white light when you‚Äôre catching up on the latest Arundhati Roy book while soaking up some sun, and move to a warmer setting for bedtime reading. The battery life is another strong selling point, as a single charge via USB-C gets you up to 8 weeks of reading ‚Äì you read that right. The Kindle Store lets you browse through more than 15 million titles from authors around the world, while the Kindle Unlimited subscription offers an all-you-can-read access to a wide catalog that includes best sellers. If you have young readers at home, you can even create a kid‚Äôs profile for unlimited access to a kid-friendly library with an Amazon Kids+ subscription.

All things considered, we highly recommend the latest Kindle Colorsoft to anyone looking to read more in 2026, especially at its current price of $200. item.title: Pok√©mon Collector Just Paid An Absurd Amount For The ‚ÄòWorld‚Äôs Worst Charizard‚Äô Card
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúI want to get this card graded,‚Äù my kid said to me yesterday about a full-art Furret he particularly loves. I looked at it closely, and pointing to a white fleck about half a millimeter in diameter on the top border I said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably not worth it.‚Äù Such is the ridiculous standard required for grading Pok√©mon cards to a level that makes them valuable. Which makes it all the more surprising that someone just paid $550 for a Gold Star Charizard (thanks WarGamer!) in such bad condition that it looks like it spent most of its last 19 years lying in a puddle.

The Gold Star Charizard is a legendary card that appeared in 2006‚Äôs EX Dragon Frontiers set, and one of the reasons that buying a sealed pack from that set will cost you around $1,000. A sealed booster box containing 36 packs could set you back $135,000. (Even the empty cardboard box that once contained the cards goes for over $200!) And the reason why is that a Gold Star Charizard in perfect condition, such that it receives a PSA grading of 10, is currently valued at over $58,000. Just loose out of the pack it will fetch you nearly $2k, and cards graded with the second-worst possible PSA rating, a 1, are priced at around $1,700. And that‚Äôs just the Zard. The Gold Star Mew in the same set fetches $7,500 in a PSA 10, and the Rayquaza ex gets as high as $3,700. There‚Äôs a lot of value to be found in those packs‚Ä¶if you‚Äôre fantastically lucky.

Or, if you‚Äôve been collecting for a while, you could go through your own collection and discover you pulled the card in 2006 without even knowing what it was, maybe played a few games with it, used it to practice flicking cards at your sister, then eventually dropped it in a pile on the floor which your mom picked up and put in a shoe box and then stored in a damp corner at the back of the attic. If so, you could have a cool $550 on your hands!

It‚Äôs impossible to overstate just how terrible the card sold by eBay seller roye_richa is. It looks like it was somehow set on fire and drowned at the same time. Listed as the ‚ÄúWORLDS WORST CHARIZARD GOLD STAR EX Dragon Frontiers 100/101,‚Äù and originally priced at a somewhat optimistic $911, the entry made no bones about the state of it.

‚ÄúLadies and Gentleman up for grabs is the worlds WORST Charizard Good Star,‚Äù begins the item description on eBay. ‚ÄúThis is a card I have had since my childhood‚Äîtechnically. I found it on the playground after a rainy day‚Äîshort to say this card is TRASHED. It barely constitutes as a card anymore it‚Äôs in such poor shape. The back of the card is ruined. The front is intact albeit again‚Äîseverely worn.‚Äù

And then again for emphasis:

‚ÄúAgain you are NOT purchasing a card of decent condition in any sense of the word. This is for the collector that needs this legendary card in hilariously awful condition‚Äîit‚Äôs truly one of a kind.‚Äù

It‚Äôs not clear where WarGamer got the detail of the card‚Äôs $550 sale price from, but the card definitely did sell to one bold collector. And, admittedly, this is the cheapest possible way to become the owner of such a card, even if it‚Äôs the most bedraggled one imaginable.
